deliberation: Looked for non-literal uses. The key imagery is the shepherds and the flock, which in context clearly refers to leaders and the people, not literal animal husbandry.

instances.english_text: shepherds who let the flock of My pasture stray and scatter
target: Judah’s leaders who misrule the people
vehicle: shepherds losing and scattering a flock
ground: responsibility to guide, protect, and keep together; failure harms the vulnerable
instances.explanation: Rulers are depicted as negligent shepherds and the people as a flock that is lost and scattered through their misrule.

deliberation: Continues the shepherd/flock imagery explicitly applied to "my people". No additional, distinct figures beyond that extended metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: הָרֹעִים הָרֹעִים אֶת־עַמִּי ... אַתֶּם הֲפִצֹתֶם אֶת־צֹאנִי וַתַּדִּחוּם
instances.english_text: the shepherds who should tend My people: It is you who let My flock scatter and go astray
target: leaders of Israel and their treatment of the people
vehicle: shepherding, scattering, and driving away sheep
ground: guidance, care, and accountability versus neglect leading to dispersion
posture: God’s accusation against leaders’ failure of pastoral care
instances.explanation: Leaders are likened to shepherds and the people to a flock that has been scattered and driven away by their actions.

deliberation: Still within the same shepherd/flock frame: "remnant of my flock," gathering, pasture, being fruitful. The language of gathering sheep and returning them to pasture is figurative for restoration of the people.

instances.hebrew_text: שְׁאֵרִית צֹאנִי ... וַהֲשִׁבֹתִי אֶתְהֶן עַל־נְוֵהֶן וּפָרוּ וְרָבוּ
instances.english_text: the remnant of My flock ... I will bring them back to their pasture, where they shall be fertile and increase
target: the exiled remnant of Israel and their restoration
vehicle: a flock restored to its home pasture and multiplying
ground: safe homeland, provision, and flourishing after danger and scattering
instances.explanation: The exiled people are portrayed as a flock brought back to its pasture and flourishing there.

deliberation: Keeps the same imagery: shepherds set over them, fear removed, none missing. This continues the leader-as-shepherd, people-as-flock metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וַהֲקִמֹתִי עֲלֵיהֶם רֹעִים וְרָעוּם ... וְלֹא־יִירְאוּ ... וְלֹא יִפָּקֵדוּ
instances.english_text: I will appoint over them shepherds who will tend them; they shall no longer fear or be dismayed, and none of them shall be missing
target: future faithful leaders and the condition of the people
vehicle: good shepherds caring for a flock so that none go missing
ground: attentive, protective oversight that eliminates fear and loss
posture: assurance of better governance under God’s appointment
instances.explanation: Faithful leaders are envisioned as good shepherds under whom the flock (people) is safe and none go missing.

deliberation: Looked for plant or other imagery. The phrase "צֶמַח צַדִּיק" is a well-known royal/messianic metaphor: a righteous branch or sprout from David’s line.

instances.english_text: I will raise up a true branch of David’s line
vehicle: a growing, healthy branch or sprout from a plant
ground: organic continuation, vitality, and legitimacy as coming from the same stock
new growth from an old root
posture: promise of a divinely established, just king
instances.explanation: A future king from David’s line is pictured as a sprouting, righteous branch emerging from the Davidic tree.

deliberation: Most of the verse is straightforward promise. The name "יְהוָה צִדְקֵנוּ" (‘YHWH our righteousness’) conceptualizes God as the source or embodiment of the people’s righteousness, functioning as a metaphorical epithet.

instances.english_text: GOD is our Vindicator / ‘YHWH is our righteousness’
target: the salvific status and right standing of Judah/Israel
vehicle: abstract quality treated as a personal name/title
ground: God is the one who provides, guarantees, or constitutes their righteousness
dependence on God for acquittal and justice
posture: affirmation of God as the ultimate source of their right status
instances.explanation: By naming the future king ‘YHWH our righteousness,’ their just standing is figuratively located in God himself.

deliberation: Formulaic oath and temporal expression (“days are coming”). No obvious metaphor, simile, or personification beyond standard historical reference.
Most is literal description of return from exile. "זֶרַע בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" (‘seed of the house of Israel’) is a conventional metonymy/synecdoche for descendants.

instances.english_text: the offspring of the House of Israel
ground: descendants originate from ancestors like plants from seed
posture: description of those whom God will bring back
instances.explanation: Uses ‘seed’ as a metonymic image for the descendants of Israel, not literal agricultural seed.

deliberation: This verse is rich in bodily and comparative imagery: broken heart, trembling bones, and two explicit similes comparing the speaker to a drunk person overcome by wine.

instances.english_text: My heart is crushed within me
target: Jeremiah’s inner emotional state under the burden of prophecy
posture: self-description emphasizing severity of response to God’s word
instances.explanation: Emotion is described as if his heart were physically broken inside him, expressing extreme inner distress.

instances.english_text: All my bones are trembling
target: Jeremiah’s whole person overwhelmed by the divine word
vehicle: bones quivering as if they had independent motion
ground: instability, weakness, loss of control under a powerful force
posture: underscoring total impact (body and soul) of God’s revelation
instances.explanation: His ‘bones’ (a synecdoche for his whole frame) are portrayed as quivering, personified as reacting to God’s word.

instances.hebrew_text: הָיִיתִי כְּאִישׁ שִׁכּוֹר וּכְגֶבֶר עֲבָרוֹ יָיִן
instances.english_text: I have become like someone drunk, like one overcome by wine
target: the prophet’s disoriented state under the impact of YHWH and his holy words
vehicle: a drunk man overcome by wine
ground: staggering, loss of normal control, altered consciousness
overwhelming influence by a powerful intake
posture: expresses how overpowering God’s word feels to the prophet
instances.explanation: He explicitly compares himself to a drunk man, to convey how overwhelmed and destabilized he is by God’s presence and word.

deliberation: Identified personification of the land mourning and a movement metaphor for moral behavior as ‘running’.

instances.english_text: The land mourns because of a curse
target: the condition of the territory and society under divine judgment
ground: visible signs of loss and sorrow, perhaps barrenness and desolation
posture: depicts judgment as affecting creation itself
instances.explanation: The land is described as if it were a grieving person, highlighting the severity of the curse.

instances.english_text: For they run to do evil (lit. their running is evil)
target: the people’s eagerness and habitual practice of evil
vehicle: running as a course or race
ground: speed, zeal, and directed course toward a goal
active pursuit rather than passive drift
posture: condemnation of their energetic commitment to wrongdoing
instances.explanation: Their pattern of behavior is pictured as ‘running’—energetic pursuit—toward evil.

deliberation: States corruption of prophet and priest, and finding evil even in God’s house (Temple). This is direct statement without figurative imagery beyond standard metonymy ‘my house’ for the Temple.
Found (1) ‘way’ as metaphor for life-conduct and (2) explicit simile likening that way to slippery paths in darkness.

instances.english_text: Their path
target: the prophets’ course of behavior and choices
vehicle: a roadway along which one travels
ground: direction, progression, and outcome over time
journey from one state to another
posture: evaluative framing of conduct as a path leading to ruin
instances.explanation: Their overall conduct is conceptualized as a ‘way’ or path, a common biblical metaphor for one’s manner of life.

instances.english_text: Their path shall become like slippery ground in the dark
target: the danger and instability of their corrupt way of life under judgment
vehicle: slippery places in darkness where one easily falls
ground: instability, unseen dangers, inevitability of falling
posture: warning that their chosen course will inevitably result in downfall
instances.explanation: Their course of life is compared to walking on slick ground in darkness, stressing how inevitably they will stumble and fall.

deliberation: Main figurative element is the verb ‘led astray’ which uses movement imagery for deception.

instances.english_text: And led My people Israel astray
vehicle: leading travelers off the correct path into confusion
ground: departure from a right course to a wrong one through someone else’s guidance
posture: condemnation of false prophets’ effect on the people
instances.explanation: Deception is pictured as causing people to wander off the right road, a standard biblical metaphor for apostasy or error.

deliberation: Detected several figures: ‘walking in lies’, ‘strengthening the hands of evildoers’, and a simile likening them to Sodom and Gomorrah.

instances.english_text: and [they] walk in lies
target: Jerusalem’s prophets’ continual practice of falsehood
vehicle: walking along a path made of ‘lies’
ground: ongoing, repeated action; a chosen route of life
being surrounded by and progressing through falsehood
posture: critical portrayal of their lies as a way of life
instances.explanation: Living in persistent falsehood is depicted as ‘walking’ in lies, treating their lies as the path they travel.

instances.english_text: They encourage (strengthen the hands of) evildoers
ground: increasing someone’s capacity and confidence to act
posture: condemns the prophets for empowering evil instead of restraining it
instances.explanation: ‘Hands’ stand metonymically for capability and action, and to ‘strengthen’ them means to empower evildoers.

instances.english_text: To Me they are all like Sodom, and [all] its inhabitants like Gomorrah
vehicle: Sodom and Gomorrah and their infamous inhabitants
posture: places Jerusalem under the same moral verdict as Sodom
instances.explanation: He explicitly compares them to Sodom and Gomorrah, invoking those cities as symbols of utter corruption and doom.

deliberation: Found an ingestion metaphor (feeding wormwood, making drink poisoned water) for bitter judgment, and a personification of ‘godlessness/flattery’ going forth over the land.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִי מַאֲכִיל אוֹתָם לַעֲנָה וְהִשְׁקִתִים מֵי־רֹאשׁ
instances.english_text: I am going to make them eat wormwood and drink a bitter draft
target: the prophets’ experience of severe divine judgment
vehicle: eating bitter wormwood and drinking poisonous/bitter water
ground: intense bitterness, pain, and possibly death from what is taken in
posture: threatens them with deeply bitter consequences for their actions
instances.explanation: God’s punishment is portrayed as forcing them to ingest bitter, poisonous substances, symbolizing intense suffering and bitterness.

instances.english_text: godlessness/flattery has gone forth to the whole land
target: the spread of corrupt teaching and behavior from the prophets
vehicle: a thing (‘flattery’/‘godlessness’) going out and spreading across a territory
ground: wide dissemination originating from a source
posture: emphasizes how far-reaching the prophets’ corruption has become
instances.explanation: ‘Godlessness’ is personified as something that can ‘go out’ over the whole land, indicating comprehensive spread.

deliberation: Saw two metonymic/figurative expressions: ‘vision of their heart’ for their own inner ideas, and ‘from the mouth of YHWH’ for genuine divine speech.

instances.english_text: The prophecies they speak are from their own minds (lit. vision of their heart they speak)
target: the inner, self-generated ideas of the false prophets
vehicle: ‘heart’ as the organ of inner vision/plan
ground: the ‘heart’ as the seat of thinking and planning
posture: denies any divine origin to their visions
instances.explanation: ‘Heart’ stands metonymically for the inner mind or imagination from which their so-called visions arise.

instances.english_text: Not from the mouth of GOD
vehicle: YHWH’s ‘mouth’ as the source of words
ground: mouth as source of spoken words
posture: asserts that their messages lack genuine divine origin
instances.explanation: God’s ‘mouth’ is a metonym for his speaking; their words are said not to come from that source.

deliberation: The key figurative expression is ‘walking in the stubbornness of their heart,’ using journey imagery for moral conduct and ‘heart’ for inner will.

instances.english_text: all who follow their willful hearts (lit. all who walk in the stubbornness of his heart)
vehicle: walking along a path defined by a stubborn heart
journey governed by an inner guide
ground: ongoing, chosen course directed by one’s inner will
continuity and determination in a chosen direction
posture: criticizes their obstinate self-direction against God
instances.explanation: Living by stubborn self-will is depicted as ‘walking’ along a path whose guide is the heart’s stubbornness; ‘heart’ is metonymic for inner will.

deliberation: The verse speaks of standing in ‘the council of YHWH’, seeing, hearing, and listening. This conceptualizes revelation as participation in a heavenly council, a metaphorical courtroom/cabinet image.

instances.english_text: But who has stood in GOD’s council
target: authentic access to God’s revelatory presence and will
vehicle: standing in a secret council/assembly where decisions are made
ground: being admitted into an inner circle, hearing deliberations firsthand
posture: distinguishes true prophets (who have such access) from false ones
instances.explanation: Prophetic legitimacy is described as having stood in YHWH’s inner council, an image drawn from royal advisers and divine council motifs.

deliberation: Clearly uses storm imagery for divine wrath: ‘storm of YHWH’, ‘whirling storm’, falling on the head of the wicked.

instances.hebrew_text: סַעֲרַת יְהוָה חֵמָה יָצְאָה וְסַעַר מִתְחוֹלֵל עַל רֹאשׁ רְשָׁעִים יָחוּל
instances.english_text: GOD’s storm goes forth in fury, a whirling storm; it shall whirl down upon the heads of the wicked
target: the outpouring of divine judgment on the wicked
vehicle: a violent, swirling storm falling on people’s heads
posture: warns of imminent and devastating judgment from God
instances.explanation: God’s wrathful judgment is pictured as a whirling tempest that crashes down on the wicked.

deliberation: Identified personification of God’s anger as something that ‘shall not turn back’ until purposes are done.

instances.english_text: The anger of GOD shall not turn back till it has fulfilled [His purposes]
target: the ongoing operation of divine judgment
vehicle: anger depicted as an agent that can advance or ‘turn back’
human emotional response as a moving entity
ground: persevering, purposeful action that does not relent until a task is complete
posture: assures the audience that judgment will run its full course
instances.explanation: God’s ‘anger’ is treated as if it were a person or force that can either continue or retreat, emphasizing its relentless operation.

deliberation: The verbs ‘sent’ vs ‘they ran’ show movement imagery: the prophets ‘run’ though not commissioned, suggesting over-eager self-promotion.

instances.english_text: I did not send those prophets, but they rushed in (lit. they ran)
target: the false prophets’ eagerness to proclaim without divine commission
vehicle: running without being sent on an errand
posture: disparages their activity as self-generated and illegitimate
instances.explanation: Their prophesying is depicted as ‘running’ though no one sent them—hasty, presumptuous action without commission.

deliberation: Again uses ‘way’ for moral conduct: ‘turn them from their evil way and from the evil of their deeds’. The core figurative item is ‘way’ as life-course.

instances.english_text: And make them turn back from their evil ways
vehicle: a ‘way’ or road one travels, from which one can turn back
ground: directionality, possibility of reversal, cumulative journey
leaving one route to take another
posture: defines true prophetic function as turning people from a bad road to a right one
instances.explanation: Sinful habits are portrayed as an ‘evil way’ from which people can be turned back, using route imagery for repentance.

deliberation: Uses spatial ‘near’ and ‘far’ for God, contrasting conceptions of divine presence; this relies on spatial metaphor for relational/ontological proximity.

instances.hebrew_text: הַאֱלֹהֵי מִקָּרֹב אָנִי ... וְלֹא אֱלֹהֵי מֵרָחֹק
instances.english_text: Am I only a God near at hand, and not a God far away?
target: God’s relational and cognitive nearness and universality
vehicle: physical nearness and distance in space
ground: being accessible and attentive vs. remote and uninvolved
posture: corrects a limited view of God’s presence and jurisdiction
instances.explanation: Physical categories of ‘near’ and ‘far’ are used to talk about God’s relational presence and universal scope, not literal distance.

deliberation: Detected (1) metaphor of God ‘filling’ heaven and earth as if they were a container, and (2) classic merism ‘heaven and earth’ for the totality of creation.

instances.english_text: For I fill both heaven and earth
vehicle: a substance filling a container (heaven and earth)
ground: all-pervasiveness, no empty place without presence
posture: asserts that no hiding place is beyond God’s presence
instances.explanation: God’s presence is pictured as filling the cosmos as a liquid or substance fills a container.

instances.english_text: heaven and earth
vehicle: the two ‘extremes’ of the created order: sky and land
ground: naming opposite or complementary parts to imply the whole
posture: emphasizes that no part of creation escapes God’s presence
instances.explanation: ‘Heaven and earth’ functions as a merism, naming two ends to indicate all that lies between.

deliberation: Reports what false prophets say: ‘I had a dream’. No clear figurative expressions; dreams are literal objects of claim.
Locates deceit ‘in the heart’ of the prophets—heart as seat of thought/intent, a standard metonymy.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲיֵשׁ בְּלֵב הַנְּבִאִים ... נְבִיאֵי תַּרְמִת לִבָּם
instances.english_text: How long will there be in the minds (lit. hearts) of the prophets ... prophets of the deceit of their own minds (lit. their heart)?
target: the prophets’ inner motives and deceptive thinking
vehicle: ‘heart’ as the locus of thought and deceit
ground: heart associated with inner life and decisions
posture: exposes falsity as arising from their own inner deceit, not external revelation
instances.explanation: ‘Heart’ stands metonymically for the inner mind/will from which their deceitful prophecies spring.

deliberation: Focus on ‘forgetting my name’ where ‘name’ stands for God’s identity/relationship; this is metonymic and conceptual.

instances.hebrew_text: לְהַשְׁכִּיחַ אֶת־עַמִּי שְׁמִי ... כַּאֲשֶׁר שָׁכְחוּ אֲבוֹתָם אֶת־שְׁמִי בַּבָּעַל
instances.english_text: to make My people forget My name ... just as their ancestors forgot My name because of Baal
target: Israel’s covenant loyalty and true knowledge of God
ground: ‘name’ represents the person, reputation, and worship of God
to forget the name is to abandon the relationship
posture: laments and condemns apostasy fomented by false dreams
instances.explanation: ‘My name’ is metonymy for God himself—his character and worship—so forgetting it symbolizes apostasy.

deliberation: Key figure is the contrast ‘What has straw to do with grain?’ where straw vs. grain represent false vs. true prophecy.

instances.english_text: How can straw be compared to grain?
target: the relationship between false dreams and true divine words
vehicle: straw vs. grain, worthless chaff vs. nourishing kernel
ground: uselessness vs. nutritive value; outward similarity but essential difference
posture: dismisses false prophecy as worthless compared to God’s true word
instances.explanation: False prophecy is likened to straw (chaff) and true prophecy to grain, stressing their qualitative difference.

deliberation: Two explicit similes: God’s word is ‘like fire’ and ‘like a hammer that shatters rock’. They are parallel but distinct images.

instances.english_text: My word is like fire
target: the effect and nature of God’s spoken word
ground: purifying, consuming, and potentially destructive power
capacity to burn away what cannot endure
posture: emphasizes the powerful, potentially destructive efficacy of God’s word
instances.explanation: God compares his word to fire, highlighting its power to consume, purify, and judge.

instances.english_text: and like a hammer that shatters rock
target: the impact of God’s word on resistant realities (people, structures, hearts)
vehicle: a hammer smashing rock to pieces
ground: irresistible power to break what seems solid and unyielding
posture: underscores the shattering, unstoppable force of God’s pronouncements
instances.explanation: The word is likened to a hammer smashing rock, portraying its power to break through hardened resistance.

deliberation: Metaphor of ‘stealing’ God’s words from each other, treating prophetic content like property that can be plagiarized.

instances.english_text: who steal My words from one another
target: prophets’ practice of copying or appropriating each other’s messages
vehicle: stealing tangible goods from a neighbor
ground: taking what does not belong to you, dishonestly appropriating
posture: condemns their borrowed or copied messages as morally equivalent to theft
instances.explanation: Their borrowing of each other’s oracles is described as ‘stealing’ God’s words, equating it with theft.

deliberation: The phrase ‘who take their tongue and say “oracle”’ is idiomatic/figurative, suggesting tongue-wagging or self-authorized speech.

instances.english_text: who wag their tongues and make oracular utterances (lit. take their tongue and say ‘oracle’)
target: false prophets’ self-authorized claiming of divine speech
vehicle: taking/using one’s own tongue to declare ‘oracle’
ground: speech originating from oneself rather than from God; tongue as source of utterance
posture: mocks their pretentious ‘oracle’ formulas as mere tongue-wagging
instances.explanation: By saying they ‘take their tongue’ to utter ‘oracle’, the text portrays their supposed revelations as just self-produced talk.

deliberation: Main figurative item is again the ‘leading my people astray’ motif, using way-finding imagery for deception.

instances.english_text: who relate them to lead My people astray
target: the people’s being deceived and misdirected by lies
vehicle: causing travelers to wander off the right road
ground: being taken off the correct route into danger/confusion
posture: condemns the prophets’ lies as actively misdirecting God’s people
instances.explanation: Once more, deception is framed as leading people off the right path into wandering.

deliberation: Here ‘מַשָּׂא יְהוָה’ (‘burden/oracle of YHWH’) is exploited in a wordplay: the technical term ‘oracle’ is treated as ‘burden’, and God responds with ‘I will cast you off’—punning on burden imagery.

instances.english_text: What is the burden of GOD? ... ‘What is the burden? I will cast you off’
target: their manner of speaking about prophetic messages and God’s rejection of them
vehicle: a physical burden that can be carried or cast away
ground: an oracle as something weighty; to call it ‘burden’ ironically provokes being treated as a burdensome object to discard
posture: ironizes their jargon and turns it back in judgment
instances.explanation: The term ‘burden’ for oracle is exploited so that, since they misuse it, they themselves become the ‘burden’ God will throw off.

deliberation: Continues the ironic use of ‘the burden of YHWH’ as a problematic phrase. The figurative force is primarily ironic wordplay, already set up in v.33.

instances.english_text: who shall say ‘the burden of GOD’
target: their flippant or formulaic way of speaking of divine oracles
vehicle: calling a message a ‘burden’ as though it were a load to carry
ground: depicts prophecy as something weighty or onerous; God turns the label back in judgment
posture: God rejects and punishes those who persist in this misuse, employing their own term against them
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘burden of YHWH’ is treated ironically: what they call a ‘burden’ becomes grounds for God’s punitive focus on them.

deliberation: Formulas ‘What has GOD answered/spoken?’ are straightforward; no notable figurative devices.

Saw two figures: (1) ‘the burden will be a man’s own word’—metaphor of word as load, and (2) ‘you have twisted/perverted the words of the living God’—metaphor of verbal distortion as physical twisting.

instances.english_text: For the burden shall be to a man his own word
ground: words conceived as a weight one must bear; they are burdened by their own speech
posture: turns their misuse of ‘burden’ back on them, making their words their own burden
instances.explanation: Their own word becomes their ‘burden’, extending the earlier pun by casting their speech as an encumbrance they must bear.

instances.english_text: you pervert the words of the living God
target: their misuse and distortion of God’s authentic revelation
vehicle: twisting/turning something from its proper orientation
ground: making something deviate from its intended shape or meaning
posture: accuses them of actively distorting God’s words, not merely misunderstanding
instances.explanation: Corrupting God’s words is pictured as physically twisting them out of shape.

deliberation: Formula questions about what God has answered/spoken, with no overt figurative imagery.
Again centers on the contentious phrase ‘the burden of YHWH.’ The figurativeness lies in the continued punning use of ‘burden’ as both technical term and weighty load.

instances.hebrew_text: יַעַן אֲמׇרְכֶם אֶת־הַדָּבָר הַזֶּה מַשָּׂא יְהוָה
instances.english_text: Because you said this thing, ‘the burden of GOD’
target: their insistence on labeling prophecies as ‘burdens’
ground: treating divine speech as something onerous or as a slogan invites God’s counter-use of the term
posture: God takes offense at their phrase and turns it into grounds for judgment
instances.explanation: Their phrase ‘burden of YHWH’ continues to function in a wordplay, where the ‘burden’ idea will recoil upon them.

deliberation: Two key figures: (1) ‘I will utterly forget you’—anthropopathic hyperbole for total rejection, and (2) ‘from my face’ as metonymy for God’s presence.

instances.english_text: I will utterly forget you
target: God’s decisive rejection and withdrawal of favor
ground: absence of active regard or remembrance
posture: threatens them with total forsaking as a consequence of their sin
instances.explanation: God’s claim to ‘forget’ them is hyperbolic language for complete rejection, not literal divine amnesia.

instances.english_text: from My presence (lit. from before My face)
target: exclusion from God’s relational and protective presence
vehicle: standing before someone’s face as being in their presence
face as seat of relational encounter
ground: face-to-face as intimacy and favor; being cast from before the face as rejection
posture: underscores the relational severing and expulsion that judgment entails
instances.explanation: God’s ‘face’ functions as a metonym for his presence; being cast from it means being expelled from his favorable presence.

deliberation: Figurative expression of disgrace ‘put upon’ them, as if shame were a garment or weight laid on them; also the ‘never forgotten’ language intensifies it.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתִּי עֲלֵיכֶם חֶרְפַּת עוֹלָם וּכְלִמּוּת עוֹלָם
instances.english_text: I will lay upon you a disgrace for all time, shame for all time
target: their enduring infamy and humiliation before others and before God
vehicle: placing something ‘upon’ them like a load or garment
ground: shame as something that clings to and covers a person, or weighs them down
posture: announces irreversible, publicly visible dishonor as part of judgment
instances.explanation: Disgrace and shame are depicted as objects laid upon them, like a burdensome garment or load that remains forever.
